pfto.hpp

00001 #ifndef BOOST_SERIALIZATION_PFTO_HPP
00002 #define BOOST_SERIALIZATION_PFTO_HPP
00003 
00004 // MS compatible compilers support #pragma once
00005 #if defined(_MSC_VER) && (_MSC_VER >= 1020)
00006 # pragma once
00007 #endif
00008 
00010 // pfto.hpp: workarounds for compilers which have problems supporting
00011 // Partial Function Template Ordering (PFTO).
00012 
00013 // (C) Copyright 2002 Robert Ramey - http://www.rrsd.com . 
00014 // Use, modification and distribution is subject to the Boost Software
00015 // License, Version 1.0. (See accompanying file LICENSE_1_0.txt or copy at
00016 // http://www.boost.org/LICENSE_1_0.txt)
00017 
00018 //  See http://www.boost.org/libs/serialization for updates, documentation, and revision history.
00019 // PFTO version is used to specify the last argument of certain functions
00020 // Function it is used to support  compilers that fail to support correct Partial 
00021 // Template Ordering
00022 #include <boost/config.hpp>
00023 
00024 // some compilers can use an exta argument and use function overloading
00025 // to choose desired function.  This extra argument is long in the default
00026 // function implementation and int for the rest.  The function is called
00027 // with an int argument.  This first attempts to match functions with an
00028 // int argument before the default one (with a long argument).  This is
00029 // known to function with VC 6.0. On other compilers this fails (Borland)
00030 // or causes other problems (GCC).  note: this 
00031 
00032 #if defined(BOOST_NO_FUNCTION_TEMPLATE_ORDERING)
00033     #define BOOST_PFTO long
00034 #else
00035     #define BOOST_PFTO
00036 #endif
00037 
00038 // here's another approach.  Rather than use a default function - make sure
00039 // there is no default at all by requiring that all function invocations
00040 // have a "wrapped" argument type.  This solves a problem with VC 6.0
00041 // (and perhaps others) while implementing templated constructors.
00042 
00043 namespace boost {
00044 namespace serialization {
00045 
00046 template<class T>
00047 struct pfto_wrapper {
00048     const T & t;
00049     operator const T & (){
00050         return t;
00051     }
00052     pfto_wrapper (const T & rhs) : t(rhs) {}
00053 };
00054 
00055 template<class T>
00056 pfto_wrapper<T> make_pfto_wrapper(const T & t, BOOST_PFTO int){
00057     return pfto_wrapper<T>(t);
00058 }
00059 
00060 template<class T>
00061 pfto_wrapper<T> make_pfto_wrapper(const pfto_wrapper<T> & t, int){
00062     return t;
00063 }
00064 
00065 } // namespace serialization
00066 } // namespace boost
00067 
00068 #ifdef BOOST_NO_FUNCTION_TEMPLATE_ORDERING
00069     #define BOOST_PFTO_WRAPPER(T) \
00070         boost::serialization::pfto_wrapper<T>
00071     #define BOOST_MAKE_PFTO_WRAPPER(t) \
00072         boost::serialization::make_pfto_wrapper(t, 0)
00073 #else
00074     #define BOOST_PFTO_WRAPPER(T) T
00075     #define BOOST_MAKE_PFTO_WRAPPER(t) t
00076 #endif
00077 
00078 #endif // BOOST_SERIALIZATION_PFTO_HPP
